For purposes other than targeting yourself or your own creatures and powering shenanigans, this card seems strictly worse than Lightning Bolt.

It's at sorcery speed, and it can potentially give your opponent a critical advantage.

Don't get me wrong, lightning bolt is hard to compete with, but this seems like a poor substitute. They should really be more subtle about letting you sneak four more copies of lightning bolt into your decks.

217977: Chain Lightning.author: Falgorn
217977: Chain Lightning.text_parsed:
@Detonativity: You have a point, in the sense that "and may choose (a) new target(s) for the copy" makes the card wordy, but it can't be a default rule. When you copy a spell, you copy everything about it, including choices that were made when it was cast. It's because you 're not casting the copy that this line of text has to be there.

@SuicidalTendancies: Actually, I'd really like to play against MasterOfEtherium, just to learn how can I speak in capitalized words :-)

Remember, except for the indestructible Stuffy Doll, you can hit your Spitemare or Mogg Maniac only once, and that the player who has the choice to pay and copy it can do so only once. You can't just hit your Spitemare (or Mogg Maniac) and pay {R}{R} {R}{R} {R}{R} to deal12 damage.

@FiveColorFinder: Consider Forgotten Cave as well.

@alblast: http://1.bp.blogspot.com/_YUN-OxtbTvg/TDLUmgxCTMI/AAAAAAAALi4/AYfM21GkDcg/s400/capslock.jpg

@limbrooke, you can't do that. You can copy it only once each time, so if you copy it again you'd have to choose to target another of your creatures or yourself, or your opponent. You can shoot your self/guys as many times as you have mana, but you only get to shoot your opponent once.

Stuffy Doll works because it puts the damage from the original and copies onto the opponent. You never change targets.

217977: Chain Lightning.author: DarthParallax
217977: Chain Lightning.text_parsed:
Red Decks are awesome. I think one day I shall make an almost-singleton Red Deck Wins. It won't be Legacy-Good, but it will be more than enough to take down most decks I want it to be able to take down.

There are too many fantastic Red cards over the years, and I want to play them all. To make room for Thunderbolt, Flamebreak and Jaya Ballard, some interesting card choices must be made.

Learn now the Lore of the Secret Fires!
First Learn the Four, the Staples,
Lightning Bolt is the Oldest, the Alpha Born, Aged as Mountains,
Chain Lightning, most Legendary, the Maddest, the Friendliest!
Fireblast is cheapest, least costly, easiest
Rift Bolt is Timey-Wimey-est


Thunderous Wrath, the Rage of God
Searing Blaze is Hottest
Chandra the Youngest, Brash and Powerful
Incinerate most droll

Grim Lavamancer is Wisest
Lava Spike osbscure, unfound, Arcane,
Jaya the Wittiest
Ball Lightning is Shocking and Relentless!

Flamebreak the most committed
Bonfire of the Damned is most Blasphemous
Demonfire is most Sinful
Banefire is Most Effective
Koth is Stone-hard

Thunderbolt, rudest
Sulfuric Vortex the Enduring
Valakut, explosive
Comet Storm the most uncontrolled
Shivan Meteor the Hugest

Torchling the Bluest
Volley of Boulders, the meaningless, the excessive, the redundant
Hammer of Bogardan, Starkest, the Thorest, Hulked, most Avengeful

234698: Ghitu Encampment.author: blurrymadness
234698: Ghitu Encampment.text_parsed:
Stellar next to instant speed burn. First strike + burn means that at 4 mana with a bolt in hand you can kill up to a 5/5 without worry. Same defensively.

Imagine nova-chaser or ball lightning, animating this is a card-advantage way to kill them while saving yourself from atrocious amounts of damage. This + staggershock in hand is like playing god. They attack with that small X/2, you just animate and kill it. They don't? You shock it to death then do the same next turn (or to the face.)

It's easy to see why man-lands are tournament staples and casual misses (most of the time.) they don't make sense except when the game is going to be close. Where making land drops is crucial, where you need every card to pull a lot of weight. This kind of land pulls a ton of weight by being both a land drop and a creature drop. Keep in mind it's a T3 first strike attacker if you need it!

234702: Fire Servant.author: Just1Micky
234702: Fire Servant.text_parsed: @Arachnos, whilst I think we would all agree that if it did it would be overpowered, I think it does not. I suspect that it affects the original damage and duplicates it. e.g. Two Fire Servants, Lightning Bolt, rather than dealing 3 X 2 X 2, it would deal 3 X 3, the original damage (3) being multiplied by both spells individually (not stacking) so, an extra 3 from one of the Fire Servants, and an extra 3 three from the other. However I am not sure if this specific ability would work in this way, so it remains an interesting, potentially game winning problem.

234702: Fire Servant.author: mrhardy12
234702: Fire Servant.text_parsed: Arachnos, the card's rulings themself state that this card stacks with itself at the following rate: 2^x, where X is the number of Fire Servants in play. That means that your Furnace of Wrath combo does indeed quadruple all damage, since 2^x is the same rate for Furnace. Basically, this card can be easy kill-shot. ESPECIALLY if you get four of this guy out. That's 2^4, or 16 times base damage. Using the Furnace increases this to a total of no LESS than 256 times the base damage of the instant or sorcery. No matter how you slice it, this guy kills. FAST.

234702: Fire Servant.author: Rendin
234702: Fire Servant.text_parsed:
@Just1Micky:

The rulings for multiple instances of Fire Servant are the same as those for Furnace of Rath.

"8/15/2010 If you control more than one Fire Servant, the effects are cumulative. Two such effects will cause damage from red instant or sorcery spells you control to be multiplied by four; three such effects will cause damage from red instant or sorcery spells you control to be multiplied by eight."

So, theoretically, with 4x Fire Servants and 4x Furnaces of Rath, you could get a сumulative 2^8x (or 256x) multiplier on any red instants or sorceries you cast. A Lightning Bolt cast under these conditions would deal a ridiculous 768 damage for {R}.

234704: Lightning Bolt.author: undergroundmonorail
234704: Lightning Bolt.text_parsed:
@SquareWhale

Kind of, not really. You can't target a planeswalker, but any damage you would deal to an opponent you can redirect to a planeswalker they control. For example, you would target an opponent with Lightning Bolt, and when it resolves choose to do three damage to their planeswalker.

Note that combat doesn't work like that; When you declare attackers, you declare them for the player and planeswalker separately.

234705: Reverberate.author: EerieTeferi
234705: Reverberate.text_parsed:
Q: If I play a Banefire, where X is 5 or more, and then Reverberate or Fork it, is that copy of Banefire also uncounterable by spells of abilities, and can that damage also not be prevented?

I got the answer on the Rules Q&A forum yesterday, and am sharing it here with you all:

A: The copy would be uncounterable as well as it copies the value of X and the abilities on it. Its damage would also be unpreventable.However, they could just counter the Fork or Reverberate.

234706: Grim Lavamancer.author: Stray_Dog
234706: Grim Lavamancer.text_parsed:
Fantastic piece of design. Exiling cards from the graveyard may feel a little strange in red, but it is an excellent solution to the idea of "how do we make a Tim that can deal 2 damage instead of just one, without it being completely broken?" Goblin Artillery is one solution at uncommon. Grim Lavamancer shows how a rare can do it, by turning your graveyard into ammunition.

Its interesting to think about the flavour of using expended burn spells as fuel for more burn. What happens to a Lightning Bolt after it has been cast? Does some spark of its energy remain buried in the ground? :O

234707: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.author: Skeletextman
234707: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.text_parsed:
I think every planeswalker had a creature/character who inspired them. Excluding Karn, Nicol Bolas, and Venser, who were inspired by their own card and character. In my opinion, I think it would go like this:

Chandra-Jaya Ballard, Task Mage: Both are red aligned hot headed pyromaniac women who love to set stuff on fire.

Jace- Arcanis the Omnipotent: Both are blue aligned wizards specializing in mind powers and mental dominance.

Ajani-Lord Windgrace: Lord Windgrace was one of the planeswalkers who joined with Urza to fight against the Phyrexians. You can see him on the cards Planeswalker's Fury and Divine Light. Although Plainswalkers of that time were not color associated, Lord Windgrace is considered to be mostly red and white, like Ajani. Lord Windgace could also be argued to be the inspiration for Gideon, as both planeswalkers enjoy being on the front lines and fighting their opponents face-to-face.

Liliana-Gwendlyn Di Corci: Both Liliana and Gwendlyn are primarily black aligned necromancers, extremely beautiful (according to the plot), and extremely manipulative.

Sorrin-Baron Sengir: Both are black aligned vampires who are more uncaring and hedonistic than actively evil.

Tezzeret-Urza: Both Urza and Tezzeret are artificers whose thirst for knowledge and power led them down a dark path (Urza fought his own brother for the Mightstone and the Meekstone, while Tezzeret's search for the Codex Etherium led him into the clutches of Nicol Bolas) Also, both were corrupted and driven mad by evil forces (Urza by Phyrexia, and Tezzeret by Nicol Bolas)

Elsepth-Serra: Both Elsepth and Serra are powerful warriors who have strong beliefs in justice and protecting the innocent. Both are also extremely merciless in the pursuit of justice.

Garruk-Kamahl, Fist of Krosa: Although Garruk and Kamahl don't seem as clearly similar as the others, Garruk takes after Kamahl in many ways. Garruk could be seen as a fusion of both sides of Kamahl. From Kamahls pit fighting days, Garruk gets his love of combat and his martial prowess, and from Kamahls redemption as a druid Garruk gets his deep respect for nature.

Nissa Revane-Eladamri, Lord of Leaves: Both Nissa and Eladamri are territorial, charismatic elves who believe in elvish superiority over all other races.

Sarkhan Vol-Rorix Bladewing: Both Sarkhan and Rorix are extreme dragon supremacists, and both have been corrupted by black magic (Sarkhan was driven insane, while Rorix was resurrected as a zombie).

Well, that's all I've got. I know I missed a few planeswalkers (Taimyo, Tibalt and Koth) but just because I can't think of the character that inspired them doesn't mean it doesn't exist.

234707: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.author: Missile_Penguin
234707: Jaya Ballard, Task Mage.text_parsed:
Each Time Spiral card was an homage to at least one previously printed card.

The card represents Jaya Ballard (http://wiki.mtgsalvation.com/article/Jaya_Ballard), a player favorite for her humorous and sadistically to-the-point flavor text quotations throughout Ice Age block. For her card, she can spellshape three different spells she was quoted on: Pyroblast, Incinerate, and Inferno; this spellshaper turns any card in your hand into one!

After the events of Ice Age, she ascended into a planeswalker and helped found the pyromancer academy which trained Chandra. This card represents her snatched out of her timeline prior to ascending to planeswalker status. Despite the seeming similarity between her three ability layout to modern Planeswalker cards, Wizards of the Coast has stated numerous times that this card was not a precursor to them.

234709: Keldon Marauders.author: ParallaxtheRevan
234709: Keldon Marauders.text_parsed:
Didn't like these for what I thought of Flavor in the 'Burninate the Everything' deck, because I think of creatures as inefficient, unreliable things that can get countered, destroyed, AND blocked, compared to burn spells that you either have the counter for or you don't....

BUT! then I read the Artifacts Cycle novels, and now I kind of want to find a place for these in some wierd Coalition flavored deck....still not sure though...they seem like more often than not they will be a 2-mana Shock, unless the opponent has no preparation for them- but in that case, you would be better off taking advantage of an unprepared opponent with a ONE mana 3/3 that DOESN'T have Vanishing.

Still- this I like a lot about them: they're quite old for being a useable common that's just fine for decks still today. The farther back you go, even if you can always spot Good Rares and Development Fail Uncommons, the commons just plain get obsoleted eventually. It hasn't happened to this one yet, and that's a good thing :)

234709: Keldon Marauders.author: Tamerlein
234709: Keldon Marauders.text_parsed:
A solid RDW card, and being a common to boot means that plenty of pauper decks will probably want this guy. When you swing with this guy on turn three it is unlikely that your opponent has any creature that has four toughness, so you are almost assure of either the three damage going straight through to their face or being able to trade with a similarly sized creature. More often or not it will be the former, because many people are hesitant to waste a removal spell on this guy because they know that he is going to die anyway.

So he is guaranteed two damage for two, is a pretty intimidating wall for any potential attackers, and he swings for three the next turn the next turn. All in all, the value he provides outweighs that the fact that you won't always be getting more than two damage from him.

4.5/5

234712: Browbeat.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
234712: Browbeat.text_parsed:
@Scumbling1: I don't often agree with your evaluations; I'm much more likely to enjoy a card for sentimental reasons that are not universally relevant for deckbuilding. Having said that, I would readily tell anyone to go and read your comments on the original printing. I think it's very valuable for people to realize (or be reminded of the fact) that putting decisions into your opponents' hands makes any spell less reliable, simply for the fact that you don't have control over the result. Neither result is "bad" - it's just that, as you keep pointing out, you'll always get the one you want less.

Anyway, I like this card! Even while recognizing that it's not as good as a flat-out burn spell (or Tezzeret's Gambit), I really only play multiplayer, and watching my friends debate about who gets to take the 5 damage this time makes me grin every time. It's the same reason that I like Menacing Ogre - sometimes the results are hilarious!

234712: Browbeat.author: Nagoragama
234712: Browbeat.text_parsed: They sure do like reprinting this card. And people sure do like defending it. It seems really good on paper, but the only good "your opponent makes a decision" cards are ones where you can set up the situation such that any choice is bad for them, such as Fact or Fiction and Gifts Ungiven. With this card, they're not going to give you 3 cards unless they are absolutely forced to. If they're in such a situation that they must give you 3 cards or die, you probably already have them on the ropes. If not, you just did 5 damage. Not bad, but red can do better things with one card. 234714: Price of Progress.author: GlassJoetheChamp
234714: Price of Progress.text_parsed:
@DrJack:

It's called a "hate card" for a reason. It gives players a huge bonus against certain cards to discourage players from them. If this makes you think twice about running lots of dual lands, then the card has done its job. No one says Seedtime is broken because it costs the same as Time Walk. No one says Relic of Progenitus is broken because it kills dredge for 2 mana. No one says Stony Silence is broken because it messes with artifacts at a cheap cost. Cards like these are all necessary for a balanced metagame because every deck has to think about what hate they'll run into, and if a single deck becomes too good, everyone can sideboard in hate to stop it.

Besides, it's not like this has done anything to stop Legacy's abundance of dual, fetch, utility, and man lands. Personally, I think that basic lands deserve more relevance in the metagame, especially since lands are quickly becoming the most expensive part of any competitive deck. Yes, this card is good enough to see some tournament action, (particularly in Delver deck) but it's nothing to get up in arms about.

234714: Price of Progress.author: DrJack
234714: Price of Progress.text_parsed:
LOL @ you guys, especially TheWrathofShane.

Dual land haters apparently believe that not only do people deserve to be punished in a spectacularly brutal manner for playing with Alpha dual lands, they actually seem to believe that those particular dual lands are the only non-basic lands in existence. I'll get to that in a moment. Firstly, if the dual land haters believe people deserve to lose games in an extremely unfair and arbitrary manner, well I guess we'll just have to *agree to disagree*. It's especially ironic to see TheWrathofShane prancing about with giddy delight over Price of Progress, up on his hind legs begging like a dog to have it reprinted, seeing as how he complains bitterly about almost every card out there for being "unbalanced". Time to pause and reflect about your values, my friend.

Now... very important... a fact that seems to go over *EVERYBODY'S HEADS*...
The Alpha edition dual-lands are NOT THE ONLY NON-BASIC LANDS in existence. Non-basic lands are universally relied upon by decks of all kinds, in all playing formats. Don't believe me? Well then, let's take a gander at some of the non-basics out there, besides those Alpha dual lands, that some players aquired a spontaneous aversion for, after being whacked across the head with a Volcanic Hammer:

--Urza's Mine, Powerplant and Tower are used by artifact-heavy decks. What do you think Price of Progress does to this deck? No, really, wipe that smirk off your face, and ask yourself, "is this really FAIR, sir?".
--Ice Age-era "pain lands". More "balanced" (and less fun) than Alpha dual lands, but they suffer just as much from Price of Progress.
--"Shock" dual lands from Ravnica - they're too balanced! Hose 'em with Price of Progress!!
--Fallen Empires sacrificial lands. Ooh! Scary! We'd better hose them with Price of Progress!!!
--Storage lands, from Fallen Empires and Mercadian Masques - Too powerful! :-P Hose 'em down!!!
--Upgrade lands from Alliances (Kjeldoran Outpost, etc.)
--Cycling lands from Urza's Saga
--Mercadian Masques depletion lands
--Artifact lands from Mirrodin
--Kamigawa legendary lands
--Legends' original legendary lands
--"Manlands" from various sets
--Fetch lands, from numerous sets - unless you always sack them immediately
--Alara rainbow lands
--Plateau and those other... HEY!! An Alpha dual land! What's THAT doing there!? DESTROY IT!!!
--Eldrazi lands like Eye of Ugin
--Vesuva and that other "doppelganger" land, whatever is was
--City of Brass, Gemstone Mine, Reflecting Pool, and many other 5-color lands that make 3, 4, and 5-color decks viable
--All manner of odd lands like Elephant Graveyard, Safe Haven, etc.
--Wasteland (HAH!!! How deliciously ironic. Serves 'em right.)

Guess what? Price of Progress brutally punishes any player using ANY of the above lands.
NOT... JUST... ALPHA... DUAL... LANDS. If you're using even a handful of any of the above, you are at risk of suffering several points of damage for just a 1R cost. If you're using a high percentage of non-basic lands (again, *not* just Alpha dual lands) Price of Progress is equivalent to 1R: Win the game. Effects like this make the game's outcome as arbitrary as flipping a coin.

All that said, if you guys enjoy using nothing but dull, dull basic lands in decks with more than one color and being mana screwed 50%-80% of the time, well a big box of chocolates for you. (the claims about 5-color decks with mostly basic lands having a 95% success rate make me laugh out loud). For the rest of us, who don't appreciate the Wizards of the Coast's irrational hatred for non-basic lands... please don't "accidentally" spill your coffee all over some moron's Price of Progress card.

Pop Quiz for the Dual Land haters, to make sure they were paying attention this time around:
TRUE or FALSE: Alpha dual lands the only non-basic lands in existence.

--City of Brass, Gemstone Mine, Reflecting Pool, and many other 5-color lands that make 3, 4, and 5-color decks viable
--All manner of odd lands like Elephant Graveyard, Safe Haven, etc.
--Wasteland (HAH!!! How deliciously ironic. Serves 'em right.)

Guess what? Price of Progress brutally punishes any player using ANY of the above lands.
NOT... JUST... ALPHA... DUAL... LANDS.  If you're using even a handful of any of the above, you are at risk of suffering several points of damage for just a 1R cost. If you're using a high percentage of non-basic lands (again, *not* just Alpha dual lands) Price of Progress is equivalent to 1R: Win the game. Effects like this make the game's outcome as arbitrary as flipping a coin.

All that said, if you guys enjoy using nothing but dull, dull basic lands in decks with more than one color and being mana screwed 50%-80% of the time, well a big box of chocolates for you. (the claims about 5-color decks with mostly basic lands having a 95% success rate make me laugh out loud). For the rest of us, who don't appreciate the Wizards of the Coast's irrational hatred for non-basic lands... please don't "accidentally" spill your coffee all over some moron's Price of Progress card.

Pop Quiz for the Dual Land haters, to make sure they were paying attention this time around:
TRUE or FALSE:   Alpha dual lands the only non-basic lands in existence.

234714: Price of Progress.text_parsed:
Turns your opponents dual lands into shock lands. Pretty cool, and can be a total blowout for just 2 mana. The best reason for playing basics in Legacy though is Wasteland and Blood Moon.

@Dr Jack: What are you on? Basic lands fundamentally suck and are nearly strictly worse than duals. Cards like Price of Progress and the above make them worthwhile in Legacy. Why are getting your knickers in a bunch and white-knighting dual lands so hard for?

234714: Price of Progress.author: OlvynChuru
234714: Price of Progress.text_parsed:
@DrJack

I think that you are missing the point. Price of Progress is well-designed because it hoses cards which are otherwise plain better than basic lands, thus making using basic lands a viable way to play the game rather than simply an inferior tactic to using nonbasics. Also, although none of the cards you listed are as expensive as Alpha lands, many of them are still really expensive (fetchlands, Ravnica shocklands, etc.). In addition, keep in mind that a land does not have to be worth 100 dollars or more for it to be way too expensive. Even if a good nonbasic only costs five dollars, that means that if you want to make your deck as good as possible, you have to spend more than 50 dollars on lands alone. Most people don't want to do that.

234721: Hammer of Bogardan.author: Aquillion
234721: Hammer of Bogardan.text_parsed:
To some of the people who don't understand the appeal: It's important to understand that when this card came out, graveyard-recursion and reusable instants or sorceries were almost unheard of. The entire buyback mechanic was basically based on this card (and a few other things, like Death Spark.)

It's a bit obsolete now, yeah; like a lot of new mechanics, they overcosted it. 8 mana for 3 damage a turn was a bit much even at the time. But it was a very important card in its day, not so much because of its raw power but because it was doing something that people hadn't really seen before and opened up new areas of design as a result.

(The fact that it was really fun to use in casual didn't hurt, of course.)

234736: Fireblast.author: Sothasil

This baby is the turn 3-4 win condition for my red deck. No red spell can do quite so much damage while surprising an opponent who got comfortable thinking you had no resources left.

Also lends itself beautifully to combo with reverberate. Can't count the number of times I've beaten someone by tapping 2 mountains, sac'ing them for FB and reverberating it with the floating mana.

Even the fact that it's target player or creature is awesome, if the game has dragged on too long for whatever reason, FB can take out creatures outside of the range of most other burns.

234737: Barbarian Ring.author: Tsunaki
234737: Barbarian Ring.text_parsed:
Okay, I am doing to do this on this card as well. I already commented on Sapseep Forest. Before you get your pants in a jiffy for linking to a Green mana source card, I might point out that they new Werewolf type is that relays on both filling the grave (in some builds) and playing a limited number of spells per turn.

Benefits: One of the few special land that DOESN'T come into play tapped, meaning it won't slow you down at all just for having it out first turn other then that one damage. In mid-late game, you can ditch a mana to deal 2 points of damage to anything on the board, great for killing off weak utility and other such cards.

Weakness: The one damage every time you tape it for Mana adds up. By the time you actually have 7 cards in the Graveyard, there will more then likely be turn 4 or 5, meaning you have given a 4 or 5 handicap over to your opponent for using this first turn, but it's usefulness is more for the "Burn 2 per turn" anyway instead of anything else I think. (Edit) You also need to sacrifice it, making that possible 4-5 damage a one time use for 2 damage, not worth it.

Rating: 2.5/5.0 - It's not worth it, I misread and skipped over "Sacrifice" there are far better cards then this.

236456: Figure of Destiny.author: blurrymadness
236456: Figure of Destiny.text_parsed:
Maybe it's:

-Regular Kithkin (1/1) but he was influential!
-He dies, but his influence carries on (2/2)
-Over time stories are built around his past and he becomes not just some guy with good ideas, but a warrior as well, inspiring others! (Imagine a warrior jesus)
-After many hundreds of years he isn't merely an epic kithkin, or profoundly intelligent warrior, but he's become legendary in his unimaginable accomplishments.

While I'm fairly sure this isn't what they intended it does (to me) represent a reasonable analog to religious figures.
